column2: Gluten sensitivity is a medical condition characterized by an adverse reaction to the gluten found in certain grains such as wheat, barley, and rye. While people with celiac disease must strictly avoid any products containing gluten, those with gluten sensitivity can often tolerate some amount of gluten without serious repercussions. Symptoms of gluten sensitivity can include bloating, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, headache, and fatigue.

Gluten sensitivity is an intolerance to the protein gluten, which is found in grains such as wheat, barley, and rye. For people with gluten sensitivity, ingesting gluten can cause symptoms like stomach pain and bloating, fatigue, headaches, and joint pain. Some people with gluten sensitivity can also develop an autoimmune disorder known as celiac disease.

Gluten sensitivity is an intolerance or an adverse reaction to consuming foods with gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye. It is sometimes referred to as non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS). Its symptoms can include digestive issues and headaches. A person with gluten sensitivity may experience abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, constipation, fatigue, muscle aches, confusion, headaches and other symptoms after consuming gluten.
